qas.question: What is "subspecies" used to indicate an objective degree of?
What is an objection to the idea of subspecies because it doesn't specify this?
What would a population have to somewhat be to be considered a subspecies?
What did Templeton argue is necessary to impose a threshold on for a population to be a subspecies?

context: Traditionally, <a0_0>subspecies<a0_0/> are seen as geographically isolated and genetically differentiated populations. That is, "the designation 'subspecies' is used to indicate an objective degree of <a1_0>microevolutionary divergence<a1_0/>" One objection to this idea is that it does not specify what <a2_0>degree of differentiation<a2_0/> is required. Therefore, any population that is somewhat <a3_0>biologically different<a3_0/> could be considered a subspecies, even to the level of a local population. As a result, Templeton has argued that it is necessary to impose a threshold on the <a4_0>level of difference<a4_0/> that is required for a population to be designated a subspecies.
